Derek, uranium is a rock?!  You have always tried to be so precise in all your other videos but here you're calling uranium a "rock".  I'm guessing (hoping) this wasn't your call and that some clueless script writer is to blame.

Uranium is a chemical element.  It isn't a mineral and it isn't a rock.  Compounds of uranium do form minerals and they do form rocks.  But calling uranium a rock is like calling a bolt a car.  Bolts can make up parts of cars but bolts by themselves are never cars.

Pedantic?  Maybe but if you were a mineral collector this point would stick out like a sore thumb.

Otherwise, the trailer looks great.  I hope I get to see the full documentary.  Nice to see Bionerd show up as well!

Anyone interested in saving the planet by moving forward a bit quicker to the hydrogen economy should read David Sanborn Scott's exceptional book entitled "Smelling Land". Incidentally he favors the use of SMRs to help get the hydrogen economy in place in a more timely manner. He is a very highly renowned expert Phd Engineering professor etc. Scientists may tend to lead but it is the engineers who tend to filter the good from bad ideas before they get released into mass production.

For those who may not yet be aware..... there are a number of newer SMR - small modular reactors that are already field proven and offer superior safety and cost benefits relative the the older/larger nuclear reactor designs.... Now I realize that many will find this hard to believe as I did initially.... Here are some examples:
1) Some SMRs are designed to burn used nuclear fuel from previous reactor designs thereby further reducing the size, mass and remaining activity of the final SMR waste material.
2) In most cases the SMRs burn and/or produce final waste that is rendered virtually useless to be used as a source material for nuclear weapon proliferation.
3) Several are configurable or specifically designed to produce hydrogen to help usher in the anticipated hydrogen energy economy just in time to get ahead of climate change nuclear disaster.

Rather than add to the list here..... just google SMRs and learn for yourself. Toshiba's 4S is one good example and then there is the travelling wave reactor that Bill Gates favors.

Also, I do hope you're going to be dispelling some of the more ridiculous manifestations of uranium hysteria. Like the absolutely false belief that the explosions of fission warheads and the explosions we've seen at the ONLY FOUR fission power plants (that had any) are related.

Because they're not.

Chernobyl blew up because it was a poorly designed water cooled reactor--kind of redundant! Because a nuclear reactor requires a lot of heat to generate power with any efficiency at all, the water is stored under extremely high pressure so it won't just boil off straight away. 
Water is hydrogen and oxygen in an ionic bond, and when it's smacked around by neutrons, it can split into free elemental oxygen and elemental hydrogen gas.
There are three things you never want to expose pure oxygen to:
high pressure, a fuel, and heat.
There are three things you never want to expose pure hydrogen to:
high pressure, oxygen, and heat.
What do you have in the reactor vessel when the water splits?
ALL THE INGREDIENTS FOR BOOM. 

It was a hydrogen combustion explosion, NOT a "Nuclear Blast" that blew up chernobyl, and people need to know the freaking difference!

We can build reactors now that have NONE of these faults! 
Molten salt as a coolant! No requirement of high pressure in the reactor vessel, no risk of building up highly explosive gases! 

... sorry, this is kind of my big thing. It's what I believe humanity needs the most right now. I just wish more people would start fighting fear and ignorance instead of feeding it. I should know you better than to feed ignorance when you've been working so hard to fight it all along.

About the topic of the documentary .. the point you are arguing is not that mainstream. We live in a fossil fuel powered world. And the world wars have been won while the nuclear weapon technology was far from being completely mastered. Japan had been defeated by conventionnal means (when it's powerfull navy ships were destroyed and the whole country embargoed) a good time before the nuclear bombings.

The claim that uranium rich rocks are the most desirable on earth is already dubious. Platinum is far more expensive than uranium and extracted in rocks of much lower "richness"(in ppm) than uranium.

Nuclear weapons have shapped the geopolitical relationships post wwII.
There are highly remarquable application of nuclear technology in the medical field.

But i couldn't argue that uranium shapped the whole modern world. (238) Uranium could open the door to a other technological era. But the basement of the modern world today is made out of coal, oil, steel, and concrete. Uranium comes far behind.
